abstract: The Upshot; research by University of Wisconsin Population Health Institute and Robert Wood Johnson Foundation finds evidence that suggests residents of communities with high income inequality are more likely to experience shorter live spans; study lends credence to theory that areas of higher income inequality will have less social cohesion and investment in education and public health.
lead_paragraph: A study found that in places with more unevenness of income, life spans were shorter.

headline.main: Income Inequality: It’s Also Bad for Your Health
headline.print_headline: How Income Inequality Can Be Bad for Your Health

snippet: A study found that in places with more unevenness of income, life spans were shorter.
